Replace some 'nested' mapping types with 'object'

A number of fields (on nova servers, hypervisors, flavors, metadefs,
recordsets) were marked with 'type': 'nested'. 'nested' is only required
where there will be arrays of complex objects which was not the case in
many of these instances. Nested fields are harder to run queries again,
and more difficult to aggregate. This patch re-types those fields to
'object' but leaves inner mappings untouched.

'object' type fields can now be listed as facets and queried
with e.g. "image.id:abc123".

Some additional changes were required in the facet term aggregation code
because previously any inner fields were considered part of a nested
mapping.

This patch requires reindexing of all data in affected types.

subject: Override name of shared baymodel
commit_message:
Override name of shared baymodel

Add a configuration directive 'allow_baymodel_name_override',
default value is TRUE. If TRUE, override name of shared BayModel
resources will be allowed, as they are today. If FALSE, the name
of new created baymodel need to be different with the shared
BayModel resources in other projects (note: if the new created
BayModel is in the same project with the shared one, then the
name of new created BayModel can be same with the shared one
whether 'allow_baymodel_name_override' is set to TRUE or not).

This way, by default Magnum allow override name of shared BayModel
and cloud operators can decide if they want to allow override or not.

In the case of clouds that want to allow sharing access to a BayModel
between multiple projects (example: a shared BayModel named 'k8s')
with 'allow_baymodel_name_override' set to TRUE, a user will still
be allowed to create a BayModel with the name 'k8s' and it will
override the shared one.

subject: Convert OVO fields to primitives for to_dict()
commit_message:
Convert OVO fields to primitives for to_dict()

to_dict() is used for conversions of OVO objects into
regular dictionaries to be used as plugin return values
to the API layer, etc. It provides the equivalent of
make_<resource>_dict that we use now (without the extension
processing). The values in these dictionaries should be
ready for representation in the API.

The issue was that the OVO to_dict() implementation was
placing complex types right into the dictionary which
would mean that the API would serialize them just by
calling str() on them (as part of json encoding). This
ignored the 'to_primitive' method defined on the OVO
type that defines how a field should be converted.
Therefore, when it came to timestamps to_dict() was
placing native datetime objects into the dictionary
which would convert to microsecond resolution, violating
the expected format of the OVO DateTime type.

This patch fixes the issue by calling 'to_primitive'
on each non-synthetic field in the to_dict() method
to ensure we match the expected format of the type before
we send it out the API.

subject: Making element overriding explicit
commit_message:
Making element overriding explicit

This is a re-factor of element_dependencies to achieve two things --
centralising override policy and storing path names.

Firstly we want to make the override policy for elements completely
explicit.  Currently, elements that wish to copy parts of other
elements walk ELEMENTS_PATH themselves and look for elements in
IMAGE_ELEMENT.  How they handle duplicate elements can differ, leading
to inconsistent behaviour.

We introduce logic in element-info to find elements in each of the
directories in ELEMENT_PATHS in *reverse* order -- that is to say,
earlier entries in the paths will overwrite later ones.

For example

 ELEMENT_PATHS=foo:bar:baz

will mean that "foo/element" will override "baz/element", since "foo"
is first.  This should be sane to anyone familiar with $PATH.
Documentation is clarified around this point and a test-case is added.

The second thing is that we want to keep the complete path of the
elements we have chosen.  We want the aforementioned elements that
walk the element list to use these canonical paths to pickup files;
this way they don't need to make local decisions about element
overrides, but can simply iterate a list and copy/merge files if they
exist.

A follow-on change (I7092e1845942f249175933d67ab121188f3511fd) will
expose this data in a separate variable that can be parsed by elements
(a further follow-on I0a64b45e9f2cfa28e84b2859d76b065a6c4590f0
modifies the elements to use this information).  Thus this does not
change the status-quo -- elements that are walking ELEMENTS_PATH
themselves and can/will continue doing that.

subject: Attempt to not set location on non active or queued image
commit_message:
Attempt to not set location on non active or queued image

Currently, an authorized user can set custom location string
to an image that is in any non-deleted status.

If a custom location is set to an image in ``saving`` status, it may
result in a race condition between the data stream that is trying to
save the image data to the backend and the custom location user is
attempting to set on the image record. This will result in a bad
experience for the user who is streaming the image data to Glance as
it is a better experiece to set the location after the image data has
been saved and image is in ``active`` status, in this case.

If a custom location is set to an image in ``deactivated`` status, the
purpose of setting the image to ``deactivated`` is void. This will
result in a worse experience for the security team that is trying to
evaluate the validity of the image data of the deactivated image.
Avoiding setting custom location in this case will ensure data
consistency until image is pulled out of the deactivation process.

This commit introduces the following change in behavior:
  * If an image is in ``saving`` or ``deactivated`` status, the staus of
    that image will be checked while trying to set the custom location
    and a HTTP 409 Conflict status will be retured in response to the
    user.
  * If an image is in ``active`` or ``queued`` status, setting custom
    locations on that image will be allowed so there is no change in
    behavior for this case.
  * If an image is in ``deleted`` or ``pending_delete`` status, a HTTP
    409 Conflict status will be retured, if that image is visible to the
    user (in case of admins). Otherwise, the location cannot be set
    anyway. Setting a location to a ``deleted`` image is fruitless as
    the image cannot be used. Please note ``pending_delete`` is another
    form of the ``deleted`` status and behavior in either case should be
    expected to be same.
  * If an image is in ``killed`` status, a HTTP 409 Conflict status will
    be retured. Nevertheless, it is again fruitless to attempt to set a
    location on such images as they are unusable.
  * This operation still involves the following race conditions:
     * In case where the status of the image is ``saving`` and it
       has just moved to ```active`` status, ideally setting custom
       location should be allowed however, due to lack of atomicity in
       setting image status glance will ignore setting the location and
       a 409 will be returned.
     * In case where the status of the image is ``deactivated`` and it
       has just been moved to ``active`` status, ideally setting
       custom location should be allowed however, due to lack of
       atomicity in setting image status glance will ignore setting
       the location and a 409 will be returned.
     * In case where the status of the image is ``active`` and it has
       just been moved to ``deactivated`` status, due to lack of
       atomicity in setting image status, glance may set another
       location on that image.
     * In case where the status of the image is ``queued`` and it has
       just been moved to ``saving`` status, due to lack of atomicity
       in setting image status, glance may set another location on
       that image.
     * In case where the status of the image is ``queued`` or ``active``
       and location is attempted to be set on it, if the image first
       goes into ``deleted``, ``pending_delete`` or ``killed`` status
       then the user will get a HTTP 409 Conflict status back. This
       occurs again due to lack of atomicity in setting image status.

Please note:
  * We will plan to add further granularity in setting locations to the
    images atomically in subsequent commits.
  * Fow now, though, this commit does resolve the issue of setting
    locations on an image incorrectly (in unexpected circumstances) to a
    significant degree. So, this is good progress in ensuring rightful

subject: Override Service provider for mon and rgw services
commit_message:
Override Service provider for mon and rgw services

On RHEL7 systems, the default Service provider is systemd.  This means
that RHEL7 hosts cheerfully ignore the explicit `status` option provided
to the `mon` and `rgw` services, which means that systemd always finds
the services in a "stopped" state because this command fails:
```
Debug: Executing '/bin/systemctl is-active mon.ceph1'
```

After this change is applied, Puppet will correctly use the `status`
command defined in these manifests:
```
Debug: Executing 'service ceph status mon.ceph1'
```

This uses the `$::osfamily` fact on RedHat and derivative systems, and
the `$::operatingsystem` fact on Debian.

Update tests to ensure that RHEL7 passes:
* set `operatingsystem` fact to "RedHat"
* set `operatingsystemmajrelease` to "7"
* change `$mon_data/sysvinit` to `$mon_data/redhat`

There are no Debian-specific tests in the original tests, and I did not
add any.

subject: Resource keystone_trust for Keystone V3 API
commit_message:
Resource keystone_trust for Keystone V3 API

[WIP] Acceptance tests still failing:
      When manipulating trusts, the credentials of the trustor are needed
      Troubleshooting why the ENV context is not working...

With Keystone API V3 support the trust capability is now available as keystone
custom type/provider by implementing [1].

Trust are uniquely identify by the ID (see Note: Trusts are unique only by their
ID).

Therefore the keystone_trust resource title is meaningless. Once created, the
trust ID is used for the resource name.

By design trusts cannot be modified, trying to do so via the puppet provider
will raise an error.

Manifest example:

  keystone_trust {'adminv3 trust user1':
    trustor_user   => 'adminv3',
    trustor_domain => 'admin_domain',
    trustee_user   => 'user1',
    trustee_domain => 'admin_domain',
    project        => 'openstackv3',
    project_domain => 'admin_domain',
    roles          => ['admin','operator'],
    impersonate    => true,
    ensure         => present
  }

To delete a trust:

  keystone_trust {'0ae2d20042d6418b8f3b8832ab43360e': ensure => absent}

Note: Trusts are unique only by their ID.
Effectively, several trusts with the same properties can exists:

  expires_at="None"

subject: support for keystone v3 api - glance
commit_message:
support for keystone v3 api - glance

Implements blueprint api-v3-support

This patch does the following:
1) This implements support for the Keystone v3 api in glance,
using the openstack provider.  Note: Does not use the v3 identity
api - the base openstack provider will use v2 or v3 depending on
the authentication parameters provided.  The auth url should not
have /v2.0 or /v3.
2) Uses the new keystone_authtoken auth_plugin 'password'.  This
allows the glance services to use Keystone v3 password based
authentication.  The glance api and registry classes have been changed
to set the required parameters in the keystone_authtoken section of
the config files, using the keystone::resource::authtoken resource.
The classes have been changed to accept user and project domains
corresponding to the auth user and tenant.  You can also pass in a
single default domain which will apply to both the user and the
tenant.
3) Uses the new keystone::resource::authtoken resource to manage
the keystone_authtoken section in the config files.
4) Allows glance to provide user domain, project domain, and default
domain parameters to resources and classes that are domain aware.

commit_message:
Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you
define __eq__ for it to work properly [1].There are no implied
relationships among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y
does not imply that x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining __eq__(),
one should also define __ne__() so that the operators will behave
as expected.

subject: Default nova cpu allocation ratio to 4.0
commit_message:
Default nova cpu allocation ratio to 4.0

The default cpu allocation ratio in nova is 0.0, which means no
overcommit. This is good for production, but not really for developers
and the gate. Since we don't have CoreFilter enabled by default, people
don't notice that the scheduler is technically overcommitting our
cpus, against the advice of this config.

Since this value is used in the brave new world order of resource
providers, we're getting warnings (which will be errors later) because
the non-resource-provider scheduler is overcommitting things. By
defaulting this to something sane for developers and the gate, we
avoid these warnings, and later errors.

Change-Id: If222f7f12fcddc3dc03ebf78b546fed51b6e8a81

subject: failed to start freezer-scheduler
commit_message:
failed to start freezer-scheduler

Edit the /etc/freezer/scheduler.conf file and
complete the following actions:
log_file = scheduler.log
log_dir = /home/tmp
use_stderr = false
no_api = true

start freezer-scheduler:
The freezer-scheduler isn't started successfully.

When start freezer-scheduler, the CONF.log_dir + CONF.log_file should
be passed to daemon.start() as parameter. Currently, the only
CONF.log_file was passed to. In the file daemon.py, the file name will
be passed to setup_logging()->configure_logging(). In the function
configure_logging(), the variable "expanded_dir_name" will be set as
"empty". So the exception was raised when creating directory to
use utils.create_dir(). The freezer-scheduler process will be aborted.

In the freezer-scheduler module, there are 2 setup_logging() funtions.
The one is in the arguments.py, the another is in the daemon.py.
The Python standard logging library is being used in the daemon.py.
We should use oslo_log instead of the logging. And the setup_logging()
in the daemon.py should be removed.

When the oslo_log is used to record the log, The freezer-scheduler
daemon can be started successfully.

Change-Id: I397cedf782d86548e7dc8bc5efc6caae9163cbd9
Partial-Bug: #1610904

subject: Performance issue for VNX attache LUN
commit_message:
Performance issue for VNX attache LUN

The VNX driver experience some performance issue during initialize
connection.

After some analysis, we root caused the problem to two issues.
1. Storage group instance was retrieved every time it's needed.  Extra
CLI calls were made to update the host LUN information in the storage
group.  These CLI calls could be saved if we cache the storage group
instance in the client.
2. Storage group instance was force updated even though we didn't do
any configuration update for the initiator port map.  This is an
implementation error.  Use `any` to check whether the list of updated
initiator port map is empty or not and do not call force update if it's
empty.
